target_question_gt: That must have been such a unique experience, seeing the same passengers and getting to know them over time. So when did things change for you in your career as a conductor?
It sounds like creating model trains brought your family together in a wonderful way. How has this hobby influenced your life now in your later years?
It's wonderful to hear how much joy model trains have brought into your life. How do you feel when you're working on your layouts, and what do they mean to you personally?
It sounds like working on your layouts is a very reflective process for you. Can you share a specific memory or story that you've tried to capture in one of your model train scenes?
So when did things change for you? When did you start to feel more settled in your new environment?
That's an impressive journey. So when did things change, leading you to work on high stakes projects like at the UN?
That must evoke a range of emotions. How do you reconcile those feelings of loss with the pride in your accomplishments?
Your journey with languages has been profound. Looking back, what do you think has been the most rewarding part of your work as a translator?
Did the incident change how people on your route interacted with you?
I'd love to hear about how you adjusted to the changes. What was it like shifting from letters to emails?
That must have been quite a shift. How did you personally adapt to this new digital world?
It seems like there was a real emotional connection in those days. How do you feel about the way things are now?
So when did things start to change in the library?
I'd love to hear about some of the core challenges you faced during this transition.
So when did the library eventually close?
That must have been hard to see such an important place in your life close. How do you feel about the future of libraries in general?
That must have been hard, but it sounds like it shaped you into the baker you became. So when did things change?
What was it like starting out in New York?
That sounds like a significant turning point. What was it like realizing you were losing your sense of smell?
It sounds like you've faced quite a few challenges throughout your life. How do you feel looking back on everything now?
That must have been terrifying. How did you cope with the possibility of losing your hearing?
N/A
It sounds like you found a new appreciation for music during that time. How did your relationship with music evolve after that experience?
I'd love to hear what your music means to you now, in this current stage of your life.
So when did things change for you after you settled in the West?
That must have been devastating, especially for a dancer. How did it happen?
What were some of the core challenges you faced during your recovery?
Teaching must have been a big adjustment. What was it like transitioning from performing to teaching?
So when did things change for you in the clockmaking world?
That must have been hard, seeing the world move in a direction that felt so different from your life's work.
I'd love to hear how you coped with those changes. Did you find a way to adapt?
It sounds like those were challenging times. How did you find a way to maintain your passion for clockmaking during that period?
That must have been hard, keeping everything in check. So when did things change for you in your career?
